Description:
Devon County Council is looking to invest into the improvement of energy efficiency of one of its key office building - Great Moor House (Exeter). The targeted energy efficiency will involve a 60% reduction of the primary energy consumption of Great Moor House. Please note the ITT provides additional information in relation to the technical requirements.
In brief, the solution must have a modelled performance (based on manufacturer information) which can over a year reduce the buildings grid supplied gas and electricity supply from a baseline of 1,578,047 kWh (averagebased on 2013-2016 annual consumption) to 631,219 kWh - a 60% reduction.

It is considered that it will be necessary to contribute additional investment to achieve the required 60% reduction of the primary energy consumption. DCC proposes that a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) will be established from which the solution provider can secure an income to recover the costs of additional investment also securing an ongoing income stream.
The solution provider will be required to sign a performance guarantee to underpin the financial performance ofthe overall solution.
The estimated project value is made up of £380,000 capital investment from DCC (including EU funding) and an estimate of a total of £1,408,000 (based on 800 kWp of PV producing 640,000 kWh per year and a PPA rateof11p/kWh for 20yrs).

Title: CP1485-17a Devon County Council - ZEBCat Devon Domestic Housing
Description:
Three social landlords are planning to invest in the demonstration of the Energiesprong approach to net zero energy retrofit their housing properties. The intention is to retrofit 15 of Exeter City Council (6 homes in Exeter) North Devon Homes (2 homes in North Devon) and Sanctuary Housing (7 homes in Torbay), requiring a single contractor to design, build and guarantee energy and maintenance performance.
This is part of the Zero Energy Buildings Catalyst project, led by Devon County Council, with the three social landlords, Regen and Energiesprong UK as partners and part funded by the European Regional Development Fund.
Energiesprong is the successful Dutch approach to self-financing net zero energy retrofit of homes. Key components of the approach include:
- average annual energy generation is equivalent to consumption per property, or as close as achievable,
- construction time on site is limited, requiring offsite solutions,
- the contractor is required to provide long term guarantee of energy, comfort and maintenance performance,
- residents pay a fixed regular service charge in return for guaranteed comfort - temperature, hot water, power and air quality,
- capital cost is financed by the landlord against guaranteed maintenance savings and service charge income,
- as the market grows to scale, increasing volume and industrialisation of offsite construction enable self-financing retrofit.
Thousands of home retrofits are now being delivered in the Netherlands, without public subsidy. It is the aim of the project partners to prove the concept with this demonstration and, if successful, to bring more properties to market subject to availability of funding.
The total fixed budget for the contract is 1 223 893 GBP including VAT where applicable.

Title: CP 1227-15 National Mapping Project Hills AONB & East Devon River Catchments
Description:
Devon County Council wishes to commission a National Mapping Programme (NMP) survey of the Blackdown Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and East Devon River Catchments. This project is part of an ongoing programme of NMP survey in Devon, grant-aided by Historic England.

Drivers for an NMP project in the Blackdown Hills AONB & East Devon River Catchments are:
•Designated Landscapes (Blackdown Hills AONB, East Devon AONB)
•Relative lack of detailed archaeological survey.
•Land management issues (e.g. catchment scale soil/water management)
•Development pressure (e.g. proposed A30/A303 dualling)

The standard products of NMP are a digital archaeological map with linked archaeological descriptions, and a report synthesising the archaeological results. Analysis of the project results should describe the character, significance, diversity, association and distribution of archaeological sites and landscapes, visible on aerial photographs, within the project area. 

The project results will also be recorded directly onto Devon and Somerset County Councils’ GIS HER layer. The Devon County HER runs on the Exegesis HBSMR platform and the Somerset HER will be on the HEROS system by the time the project is underway. Devon County Council uses ArcView GIS software.

The project will be based at County Hall, Exeter. Workstations for up to two full time project staff will be provided, including PCs, GIS software and access to the Devon HER and supporting digital records. County Hall smartcards will be provided, which will enable access to the staff carpark for 3 days per week (£1 charge per day and space permitting). Remote access to the Somerset (HEROS) HER will be provided, enabling data input directly from County Hall, Exeter. Should a more intensive staff resource be required or suggested, this can be discussed prior to the submission of tender, however space for more than two staff cannot currently be guaranteed.

The size of the project area and grant will require a project in three phases 
•Preparation of a full Project Design to Historic England standards.
•NMP survey of Project Area1.
•NMP survey of Project Area2

Title: CP1436-17A Call Centre Services
Description:
Devon County Council (DCC) Require an intelligent, highly configurable contact centre technology solution to sit on top of our SfB infrastructure to service the contact centres listed in the invitation to tender and with the flexibility to provide additional sites, or different combinations of sites, as business requirements evolve. The solution should also provide Voicemail facilities for SfB users, flexible call queuing, IVR and directory services with speech recognition, whereby callers can ask for a member of staff, or a service by name.
The expected total contract value is between £600,000 and £800,000 this is based on (10) ten year period. Devon County Council (DCC) operates an internal voice/telephone network which comprises 13 Unify Realitis DX TDM PABXs and a Unify dual node OpenScape Voice VOIP platform. These are linked together via proprietary SIP Trunking running across a managed service MPLS network.
The network hosts about 7,000 extensions, spread across approximately 40 sites. Most extensions have an associated DDI number for incoming calls.
DCC has moved to a more flexible method of working and uses a speech recognition directory to send calls to the users' nominated device, whether this is a desk extension, mobile, home line or a handset in a partner's location. This is provided by a dual node Netcall Liberty platform. This platform also provides our voicemail service and some IVR and auto attendant services for some of the smaller contact routes into the authority.
DCC also operates a 60 seat contact centre, based in Tiverton which deals with the majority of incoming calls from the public for Council services. This includes, but is not limited to; Devon Highways, Adult and Children's Social Care, Registrars and General Enquiries. This is based on a Unify Realitis DX PABX with intelligent call routing and reporting provided by OpenScape Contact Centre (OSCC).

Title: CP1494-17 A361 and A39 North Devon Link Road Geotechnical Investigation
Description:
This Contract involves the Geotechnical Investigation into the A361 / A39 North Devon Link Road from the Borner's Bridge Junction at South Molton to the Buckleigh Road Junction near Bideford.
The ground investigation will comprise the following works:
•	The excavation of mechanically dug trial pits to a maximum depth of 4m or refusal.
•	Windowless sample borehole drilled by a dynamic sampling rig to depths as given in the Procurement Documents or refusal on rockhead. This is to include in-situ Standard Penetration Testing (SPT) and undisturbed sampling.  Hand-dug starter pits shall be excavated at all exploratory borehole locations.
•	Combine dynamic sample / rotary open hole / rotary cored boreholes to depths as given in the Procurement Documents . This is to include in-situ Standard Penetration Testing (SPT) and undisturbed sampling. Hand-dug starter pits shall be excavated at all exploratory borehole locations.
•	Excavation of hand-dug trial pits in sides of existing cuttings and removal of vegetation to expose underlying rock mass to facilitate kinematic analysis.
•	Excavation of hand dug pits at base of cutting where inaccessible to mechanical excavation/boring methods.
•	Installation of groundwater monitoring standpipes in boreholes to a depth specified by the supervising engineer. Monitoring standpipes shall be 19mm diameter or greater.
•	In-situ determination of California bearing Ratio (CBR) - to be undertaken using Dynamic Cone Penetration (DCP) equipment. The number and location of DCP tests required to provide sufficient coverage will be determined on site by the Investigation Supervisor.
•	Groundwater monitoring is to be conducted following the completion of site works at intervals determined by the Investigation Supervisor. All installations shall be monitored to establish the elevation of groundwater.
•	Geotechnical Laboratory testing on selected samples.
•	Environmental/Chemical Laboratory testing on selected samples. 
•	Specific borehole requirements and Borehole location plans are detailed within the Procurement Documents.
•	Provide Devon County Council with a Ground Investigation Report and Interpretation Report, plus design support. The Canal within the Country Park is an 11 mile long nutrient rich water body which every year between early spring and late autumn chokes up with a range of native and invasive alien water plants. The increase in invasive alien species and changes in weather patterns with more extreme storm events flushing in large volume of silt and nutrients this has increased the volume of weed needing to be cleared in order to keep the waterway open for recreational and business use.  The canal ranger service has one weed harvesting boat but this is becoming increasingly unreliable with frequent breakages and long periods of downtime awaiting parts for repairs, resulting in huge backlogs of work if the weather is suitable. Keeping the canal channel clear of weed is also very important in safely managing canal water levels during severe weather events.  The canal rangers service wishes to purchase a new weed boat, initially at least to compliment the existing one, although in the medium term the existing boat may become uneconomic to repair.  Rather than purchase a replacement weed harvester boat with the inherent large number of moving parts and separate mechanisms that are all liable to breakage, we wish to procure a simpler boat that cuts and then rakes up the cut material to deposit on the canal banks for collection.

Title: CP1720-19 Connecting the Culm
Description:
Connecting the Culm is a 3-year, £1 million partnership project, part of a £7 million Co-Adapt Programmeled by Somerset County Council. This project has received funding from the Interreg 2 Seas programme 2014-2020 co-funded by the European Regional Development Fund. The programme will tackle some significant challenges posed by the River Culm and its catchment. The project will employ a multi-agency team working across thecatchment to deliver the project, comprising specialists in natural flood management,community engagement and biodiversity.
The Procurement consists of seven lots. Lot No: 1 - Co-creation Specialist. Co-creation Specialist. This 1 Full Time Equivalent contract role will engage communities and stakeholders to foster collaboration and embed co-creation throughout the project lifecycle (£137,000). Lot No: 2 - Whole river catchment study.  Develop a robust nature-based solution modelling tool to enable sound decision making, adopting adaptive planning principles. The tool needs to encompass and interrogate: scenario planning (climate change), ecological networks, catchment based mapping tools and floodplain reconnection feasibility (£75,000). Lot No: 3 - Hydrological monitoring. Install equipment and undertake hydrological monitoring (including flow and water quality) of nature based solution interventions in order to measure change (£70,000). Lot No: 4 - Co-creation evaluation. Establish a baseline to assess current levels of community engagement and undertake on-going evaluation and monitoring of key audiences / stakeholders in order to measure collaborative change (£20,000). Lot No: 5 - Nature Based Solutions Specialist. This 1 Full Time Equivalent contract role will work with landowners, farmers and other stakeholders to co-create, develop and oversee installation of nature based solutions in priority sub-catchments (£137,000). Lot No: 6 - Education specialist. Undertake curriculum based activity with 3 catchment schools (primary and secondary) (£9000). Lot No: 7 - Habitat restoration monitoring. Title: CP1689-18 Digital Platform Development Support
Description:
DCC is responsible for issuing Blue Badges to residents of Devon. Applications are either submitted via a DfT operated online service or directly G-to the DCC contact centre. DCC assesses each application and determines whether to award a Blue Badge or invite the applicant to a mobility assessment. DCC also undertakes ordering of badges. The current business process is inefficient, relying on paper documents, rekeying of information into an Adult Social Care system, and lacking basic requirements such as customer notifications. DCC is pursuing a digital transformation agenda and has procured the Outsystems low code platform to develop services. The Blue Badge service is the first new digital service to be built on the platform. Development work is scheduled to commence 1st February 2019 and must be completed no later than 31st March 2019.

A discovery exercise involving workshops, user research, etc. has identified user stories the new digital service will ideally meet. The user stories are contained within the product backlog. The list is undergoing constant iteration. It has undergone initial prioritisation but deliverables in relation to the Minimum Viable Product and subsequent releases have yet to be determined.

DCC requires a partner who can lead development of the new Blue Badge digital service. The organisation will have substantial experience of Outsystems and will be capable of meeting complex project requirements. Responsibilities will include leading the development activities within a multi disciplinary team in order to deliver a new blue badge digital service in accordance with the product backlog. This will include but is not limited to sprint planning, estimation, release planning, exploration of technical options, development of digital service using agile (scrum / kanban influenced) approach, versioning, testing, and assigning tasks and assessing output of a junior developer.

The partner's allocated resource will be part of a team that is currently being established but will include the following DCC resources: delivery manager (acting); junior developer (0.5FTE); content designer (0.5FTE); user researcher (0.5FTE equivalent); and technical architect (0.2FTE). The team will be established for 6 x 2-week sprints, corresponding to 12 weeks in total, commencing 14th January 2019 and will be based at County Hall, Exeter. Title: CP1098-14 Buildings Based Day Services – Entry Point 12
Description: Buildings based day services could offer a whole or half day of service or could offer discrete activities or sessions that people might chose to attend. Buildings based day services will be of value as a meeting point, for providing a flexible 'drop-in' for people at times of their choosing, for providing access to facilities suitable for people with disabilities (i.e. toilets and kitchen areas, meeting rooms), for providing a access point for information advice and signposting, for providing spaces for one to one support and small group activities. But as much as possible the building should take the form of an ordinary facility, preferably one that can be used by anyone in the community, regardless of whether or not they have health or disability related difficulties and located within and with easy access to, community services and facilities. Furthermore buildings based services will increasingly provide a space, facilities and support to people who are attending activities run by external voluntary and community groups and other organisations. Incidental to the provision of meaningful activity for people attending buildings based day services, services can also provide respite for carers. The ability to offer person centred activities for a whole day or half day with integrated support and if necessary care, can allow carers to take a significant break from caring responsibilities. Increasingly people who receive social care funding wish to take up mainstream social and cultural opportunities, and to build broader social networks. They want to receive support and partake in activities that are personalised around their needs and theirs and their carers wishes. Traditional services have been less effective in enabling these sorts of opportunities. Building-based services have a role to play in supporting people to maintain and extend social networks and access to mainstream roles and activities. This specification describes the Councils approach to modernised buildings based day services. This Specification is not related to a community enabling or community facilitation offer, whereby a number of hours of support which enables or facilitates access and use of services and activities open to all (universal services). Community enabling or facilitation is commissioned as appropriate via the Personal Care and Support Framework.
